qas.question: What is the sole fissile isotope that occurs in nature?
What can be turned into plutonium-239 in a nuclear reactor?
What uranium isotope is produced from thorium?
Along with uranium-235, what isotope is noted for having a high fission cross-section for slow neutrons?
What is the sole fissile isotope that occurs out of nature?
What can't be turned into plutonium-239 in a nuclear reactor?
What uranium isotope is produced into thorium?
Along with uranium-235, what isotope is noted for having a low fission cross-section for slow neutrons?

context: Many contemporary uses of uranium exploit its unique nuclear properties. <a0_0><b5_0>Uranium-235<b5_0/><a0_0/> has the distinction of being the only naturally occurring fissile isotope. <a1_0><b6_0>Uranium-238<b6_0/><a1_0/> is fissionable by fast neutrons, and is fertile, meaning it can be transmuted to fissile plutonium-239 in a nuclear reactor. Another fissile isotope, <a2_0><b7_0>uranium-233<b7_0/><a2_0/>, can be produced from natural thorium and is also important in nuclear technology. While uranium-238 has a small probability for spontaneous fission or even induced fission with fast neutrons, uranium-235 and to a lesser degree <a3_0><b8_0>uranium-233<b8_0/><a3_0/> have a much higher fission cross-section for slow neutrons. In sufficient concentration, these isotopes maintain a sustained nuclear chain reaction. This generates the heat in nuclear power reactors, and produces the fissile material for nuclear weapons. <a4_0><b9_0>Depleted uranium<b9_0/><a4_0/> (238U) is used in kinetic energy penetrators and armor plating.
